definitions.definition: to jump into water with your head and arms going in first
definitions.sensetop: dive (from/off something) (into something)dive off somethingdive in

examples.text: We dived into the river to cool off.
Sam walked to the deep end of the pool and dived in.
He dived head first into the water.
She dived from the top diving board.

definitions.definition: to swim underwater wearing breathing equipment, collecting or looking at things

examples.text: The main purpose of his holiday to Greece was to go diving.

definitions.definition: to go to a deeper level underwater

examples.text: The submarine dived to avoid being seen.
The whale dived as the harpoon struck it.

definitions.definition: to go steeply down through the air

examples.text: The plane dived down to attack.
The plane suddenly dived from 10 000 feet to 5 000.
Unlike some birds, it does not dive vertically.

definitions.definition: to move or jump quickly in a particular direction, especially to avoid something, to try to catch a ball, etc.

examples.text: We heard an explosion and **dived for cover** *(= got into a place where we would be protected)*.
The goalie dived for the ball, but missed it.
It started to rain so we dived into the nearest cafe.
He dived headlong into the ditch.

definitions.definition: to fall deliberately when somebody tackles you

examples.text: The share price dived from 75p to an all-time low of 50p.

wordOrigin: Old English dūfan ‘dive, sink’ and dȳfan ‘immerse’, of Germanic origin; related to deep and dip.
